Common questions about arc mold and radi: Common questions about arc mold and radius bending tooling
Bump forming uses standard V-dies and pu: Bump forming uses standard V-dies and punches with CNC programming to create large radius arcs through multiple small incremental bends (approximating the arc with linear segments). Dedicated radius tooling uses specially profiled punches and dies to create smooth radius bends in a single operation. Bump forming is cost-effective for occasional large radius work, while dedicated radius tooling provides superior surface finish and faster production for regular radius bending applications.
Use urethane dies when bending pre-finis: Use urethane dies when bending pre-finished, pre-painted, or polished materials where surface marking is unacceptable. Urethane provides mar-free bending ideal for architectural panels, appliances, decorative metalwork, and any application where surface quality is critical. Steel dies are preferred for higher production volumes, harder materials, or when surface marking isn't a concern. Hybrid steel-urethane combines both benefits.
The punch radius should be at least 63%: The punch radius should be at least 63% of material thickness to prevent stress concentration. For air bending, the internal radius forms at approximately 15-20% of the V-die opening width. Match your punch tip radius to the natural internal radius created by the die opening for consistent angles. Consider material springback (stainless steel requires 1-2째 compensation). Consult our technical team with your material specifications for optimal radius selection.
Yes, we specialize in custom radius tool: Yes, we specialize in custom radius tooling for unique applications. Provide your required radius dimensions, material specifications, production volume, and part drawings. Our engineering team will design custom arc molds optimized for your specific application. Custom tooling is particularly cost-effective for high-volume production runs requiring consistent radius specifications not available in standard tooling catalogs.
Maximum achievable radius depends on pre: Maximum achievable radius depends on press brake table width and tooling system. Standard radius punches typically range from R5 to R100mm. Large radius tooling systems can achieve R120-R200mm. For radii exceeding these limits, bump forming can create virtually any radius through programmed multi-step bending. Large radius applications may require specialized extended-reach tooling or custom engineered solutions.
Springback increases with material hardn: Springback increases with material hardness and decreases with larger bend radius. To minimize springback: use properly matched punch radius (63% minimum of material thickness), apply sufficient tonnage for bottom bending rather than air bending, compensate bend angle 1-2째 for stainless steel, use larger die opening to reduce stress, and consider coining for zero springback applications. Material-specific springback tables help predict and compensate for springback in production.
Get comprehensive technical specificatio: Get comprehensive technical specifications, radius charts, material options, and application guides for our complete range of arc mold and radius bending tooling.
